This is a Jig to wrap the perfect coil.

After printing your jig you'll need to find a 3mm diameter and 30mm long rod. I used a nail that inserted in a drill an spun and polished with sandpaper. insert the rod in the hole, heat up the back end of the rod and put the rob to go a little inside your jig.  grab a little of extra filament and heat it up and fill in the back end of the hole.

I reached into the way back machine to modify this design. While my wife was putting together her PolyBot, she cut her finger on the sharp corners of this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5126 As much as I love that design, it was innevitable that sharp corners would cut someone. My wife's comment was; "If you're going to have kids assemble this, there can't be any sharp corners". This thing takes a different direction than the socket based joint. Instead of using 'sockets', it uses protrusions that can grab onto the dimples of another thing. In this particular case, it will match well with this other thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8272 Combined, they form a vertex/joint that can bring together three rods of any size. A nifty thing for building space frames. You can change parameters in the OpenScad to adjust the size of the protrusions, or the width of the slot, or whatever.

1) Print a few of these
2) Insert dimpled things for the protrusions to grab
3) Rejoice! This design is based on what I would call 'progressive friction holding'. That is, there are no fasteners. The hub is somewhat flexible, so the first thing you put in place will go in easily, due to that flexing. The second one will go in harder, because there's less flex available, and thus more friction. The last one should be downright challenging to get in, but once in, all three should be fit in very snugly, with nothing more than the friction holding them in place. If you find that you've got the angles you need, you can pour a bit of epoxy or whatever ABS melting/binding/hardening thing you have, over the joints, and things can be solidified.

title: Z Endstop Montaj Parçası - Z Endstop Carriage With Solidpart

description.text:
Z endstop'u z mili üzerinde ayarlanabilir bir şekilde sabitlemek için tasarlandı, umarım işinizi görür.  
I've made of this part for easy configure z endstop measure. I hope enjoy with it.

Metrik 4, 10-12-14 uzunluğunda vida ve somunla endstopa montajlayın, sonra parçayı tutamaklarından z miline yerleştirin. Yüksekten başlayarak z endstop mesafesini ayarlayın.  
Use metric 4 screw 10-12-14mm lenght for assembly z endstop and printed part. Then place that on 8mm z mile/shaft. begin high distanse to low until perfect position for your nozzle.

Our Redsail laser had the X-axis flipped, things came out mirrored around X. The included Autolaser software had no way of correcting for this (!), so we decided another fix.
Adding another endstop allowed us to flip the axis in firmware settings. Slips onto the carriage without screws. Recommend double-sided tape to make it not so easy to lift off. Github: https://github.com/jonnor/projects/tree/master/practical3d

This is the clock script for the current version of the test jig, which has been improved based on feedback from rustedrobot who printed out several iterations of the printable clock project, and several other makers on thingiverse with particular expertise on gears. Current development version to be found on git hub here:
github.com/syvwlch/Printable-Clock-Project It requires my clock builder script, which in turn requires the MCAD/involute_gear library and my clockwork library. Particular improvements include:
  • herringbone gears, with suitable clearances.
  • no concentric shafts, no hands.
  • lowered pressure angle (14.5 degrees instead of 28).
  • minimum number of gears needed to test the escapement.
  • flanged drums on all wheels.
  • escapement/pendulum shares a shaft with the gear-train.
  • two-piece, connected frame to hold the shafts without applying pressure to the gear train.
  • thicker gears.
  • minimal sleeves to ensure clearance.
    • (UPDATE: if run using the latest clock-builder script, the escapement wheel will use club teeth, which should print better than the original ratchet wheel (thanks ssd, for the feedback on the original one).
    I have uploaded the two modified parts, the escapement wheel and the escapement, as parts 02b and 03b respectively. The rest are unchanged and do not need to be reprinted.) (UPDATE: the club-tooth version described above has been tested by TheRuttmeister and it passed all four tests! Major milestone. :-D We're going to work on mounting the string on the drum, rewinding it, and on a actual functional pendulum.) (UPDATE: rustedrobot has also printed out the club-tooth version and with some post-print fine-tuning, got it to run for two minutes powered by a weight on a string! Video here: http://www.prototribe.net/vidplay/testjig2.html ) (UPDATE: improved back frame available, part 5b, which now includes countersunk hexagonal holes to hold the bolt heads and sit flush with the wall, as well as two wall mounting holes, same diameter as the bolts.) (UPDATE: added a version of the drum with holes for attaching string, part 1b) (UPDATE: part 03c is a variant of the escapement with increased drop, i.e. smaller impulse faces. The intent is to remove the need to shave the teeth before it works.)

Print one of each STL file, or fiddle with the parameters, check your work with the assembled view, and then generate a new STL for each part, and print those.
(UPDATE: Parts 02 and 03 have already been tested and the ratchet teeth print out too short. Please print out and test parts 02b and 03b instead!)
(UPDATE: with some manual post-processing, parts 02b and 03b do tick. There is also a part 05b available with improved frame features. Recommend you use all b variants available.)
(UPDATE: to avoid drilling a hole in the drum to attach the string, print part 01b instead!)
This test jig requires two shafts to slip the sleeved gears over, and another two to hold the frame together, outer diameter 3mm with a clearance of half a millimeter either side, so M3 will work... without drilling!

Test #1: with the escapement (03) in place, are there any escapement positions for which the escapement wheel (02) can rotate freely?
If yes, test failed.
Test #2: without the escapement in place, can the escapement wheel be made to turn by applying moderate torque to the drum (01)? How much flex is there in the frame during this test?
If no, test failed.
Test #3: with the escapement in place, and with moderate clockwise torque applied to the drum, does swinging the escapement slowly back and forth cause the escapement wheel to 'tick' forward by one tooth for every swing?
If no, test failed.
Test #4: repeat test #3, but instead of swinging the escapement back and forth, slowly push the escapement until the escapement wheel 'ticks'. When it does, does the escapement jump ahead a little, indicating that the wheel gave it an 'impulse'?
If no, test failed.

comments.text: Part 03c seems to work as-is with an unmodified escapement wheel. It will be useful to know if others have the same luck. One thing I noticed is I think the clock ticks faster with it, but i can't be positive.
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: That's interesting... Based on the video, I think it may be possible that the club-tooth escapement wheel is over-driven by the escapement, at least with 100g geared down by only 1:4. By that I mean that the impulse provided is too strong, and the pendulum is being shoved around, not gently nudged. It did seem a little slow for its length.
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: Still not made a pendulum, but the new part 03c works great for me too.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: I printed 3c, and it seems to work, but I haven't tried putting force on the drum yet.

comments.text: So part 03c works as printed with an as-printed part 02 (pointy-tooth escapement wheel) and an as-printed part 02b (club-tooth escapement wheel)? Excellent!
comments.author: ssd

comments.text: The pendulum needs to be rigid, otherwise it won't impart force to the escapement.
comments.author: ssd

comments.text: Started working on making a snap-fit compound pendulum, since rustedrobot is doing such a great job on the winding drum :-)
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Confirmed SSD's findings on the original escapement. If I had to guess, the last 1-2mm of the escapement wheel's teeth are missing (and the pallets are probably rounded off a little as well). I'm guessing skeinforge didn't even try to put plastic there because it fell under a minimum width threshold. People printing with narrower extruded diameters may have better luck, but overall it will be a hard thing to print.
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: Yeah, club-tooth is better all around I think... but clearly it's not printing exactly as designed either!
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: Yes. I'm thinking a good goal would be a printable escapement where the only modifications necessary are to the pallets. Modifying the escapement wheel teeth offers too much potential for variation on a per-tooth basis. Keeping hand-modification to the pallets should be far more managable for now.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Bevels should be easy. For the teeth, it sounds like you think they need some changes, i.e. that it is not enough to hand-modify the escapement... What do you think needs to change? Overall radius? Size of the club? Angle?
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: Here are a few pics covering some of what i've encountered. In the hand-modifed pic the angles are closer to 30deg, so i'm not positive exactly whats best. I think 45 will be more forgiving towards variations in the pallets.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Thank you, that's very good info, and it looks very similar to what ssd ran into on his print.
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: Mine suffers a similar problem.

comments.text: I'll put up a modified escapement and a modified wheel tomorrow. They probably won't work quite right but hopefully they will be closer to the mark fresh off the printer.
comments.author: TheRuttmeister

comments.text: I can't think of how you can make a windable drum without it being 3 seperate prints!
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: I was thinking of having the drum slide over a tall saw-tooth gear stacked on the gear wheel, and have the ratchet be a set of springy arms extending from inside the drum. They'd bend out of the way of the saw-teeth one way, but push against them the other. Two parts.
comments.author: TheRuttmeister

comments.text: There's a way to do the drum without support material. I'm going to finish the hacked up version I started last night hopefully this evening. In a nutshell, the ring of saw-teeth on the gear are truly a ring (hollow centre), so the struts for the drum axle hop over the teeth with 45deg angles.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: sounds interesting, although I'm not sure I understand how you are going to manage to get things springy.

comments.text: ooo, clever.

comments.text: So I increased drop (the angular distance between when one tooth drops free of a pallet and when the next tooth hits the other pallet) by 3 degrees by slimming down the impulse faces of the pallets. See below the before/after pictures.

comments.text: @TheRuttmeister - Yes, the holes won't print properly, but the ugly part will be hidden by the captive nut anyway. I tried it with a 6mm round hole which was be a bit larger than the hex holes and the holes came out surprisingly well. After a layer or so everything is back on track.
comments.author: TheRuttmeister

comments.text: I made the hexagonal hole 6mm corner to corner, but that's a parameter if it needs to be enlarged a smidge. How deep does the hole need to be, at a minimum, to sink the entire head of the bolt?
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: The standard nuts i have are 2.28mm thick, I also have a few nyloc nuts that measure 3.90 - 3.92 thick. (Figured the nyloc might be nice on a permanent/final version.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Depends how many different versions you guys are willing to print, I guess. :-)
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: I have no problems printing many variations. =)
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: @TheRuttmeister: I'll post the clock w/ and w/o the concentric shafts.
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: I would suggest we go with a minute and second hand, at least if we go with concentric shafts. might be worth making a test jig for testing the fit of those. I think 0.2mm clearance will be the minimum we need. without concentric shafts we can just go to the full clock.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Yeah, if we ditch the concentric shafts, we should do a complete clock, but with little drums on each gear, just in case. We'd find out how far along the gear train we can power this thing...
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: I'm sure I've seen clocks with multiple weights (in fact I don't think I've seen a long clock with less that 2). If you can throw together a full clock I'll start printing it on monday (hopefully, I need to finish fixing my cupcake upgrade). I think we should work on the concentric shafts and the geartrain effiency seperatly. We can just print a couple of concentric shafts to play with clearance issues and print the the full clock to play with the other issues that will no doubt pop up.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: I mitered the countersunk holes for half their depth, to transition from the hexagonal, wider hole to the round, smaller hole. Perhaps mitered is not the right word. Attached is a closeup of the modified countersunk hole. Let me know what you think?
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: IOW, there is a 3mm deep, 6mm diameter hexagonal hole, which transitions over the next 3mm of depth to a 3mm diameter round hole which runs for the rest of the frame's thickness. Worst case at the corners, 1.5mm less distance radially over 3mm distance axially, should print fine.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Looks awsome. Although I found that a 6mm round hole works just as well (provided you are using socket cap bolts). An m3 nut will just bite enough into the walls to be captive and the head of the bolt will fit perfectly if you want to use it the other way around. And it can be tapered the same way down to the 3mm hole.

comments.text: Worked! Printing the last part of the frame (and cursing the fact that I don't have more long m3 bolts).
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: A hole in the drum would be good! In an earlier failed test print on jig#1 I'd added the hole into the drum with a via a hand drill. Ideally the hole would be small enough to let the string/line in, but knotted it wouldn't let it back out. 1-2mm would be good. Now the question is which side of the drum, closes to the gear or furthest?
comments.author: TheRuttmeister

comments.text: I made one too, 3mm works fine with most string (you can just make the knot bigger).
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: I'm just tooling up this test jig now. Was planning on using fishing line for the string (should be able to fit lots of it on the drum!).  I was figuring the placement on one end or the other was so that the string when coiled could make nice even layers. Not sure how practical that will be tho.
comments.author: TheRuttmeister

comments.text: I think you are both over thinking it, both ends of the string are effectively fixed. It will naturally find its own path and shouldn't bind.
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: I over think everything. =)
comments.author: TheRuttmeister

comments.text: If it's worth thinking, it's worth over... no, wait.  :-[
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: I'll put adding the hole on the issues list on GitHub. :-)
comments.author: TheRuttmeister

comments.text: Cool! Any recommendations on how to make that hole so it prints ok? I'm not well versed in hoverhangs and bridges and such... isn't there something about tear-drop shapes for holes?
comments.author: TheRuttmeister

comments.text: For small holes it doesn't matter. A 2-3mm hole would be fine. much above 4-5mm and you start getting droopyness, but I print unmodified 10mm holes without too much trouble (and that involves big overhangs).

comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: I couldn't stand waiting any longer and went ahead and built this.  (Am I the first?)  Your gears are beautiful.  I'm not sure if the tolerances of my machine are off, but the escapement doesn't quite bite deeply enough into the teeth.  I'm out of long screws to hold it together, so its kind of jury rigged, so that doesn't help either.  But it's a beautiful thing anyway.  :)  I almost wish I had printed the parts in different colors to make the gears stand out more.   Let me know if you want more detailed feedback.
comments.author: ssd

comments.text: Thank you! Both for printing it out and for the feedback. :-)

author: Kerkove

description.text:
Decorate your bathroom in a moment with the "Bellflower Toothbrush Stand", which combines function with beauty with a six-piece easy print and assemble design.  
Please leave a comment or a tip if you enjoyed this.

Print at 0.2 mm layer height, with 10% infill. This uses 72 g of filament and takes 16 hours and 43 minutes.   
Print the parts without support at 0.2mm and 25% infill. At 4mm^3 per second - this took me seven and a half hours to print.   
Or print at 0.1mm for better quality with supports only for the base part.  
Note: The assembled file is for preview purposes only.

comments.text: This was a little rough to print all 3 arms together.  So I used s3d and separated them, then placed them 180 from final use.  Meaning that the largest loop is on the bed.  I printed 1 too about 3 hours.  now I am printing 2 more (~5 hours)  I did use supports and looks great.  I will update a make once it is all done.

title: Portal 2 Turret
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Some other turret models have been posted and people have been asking for the model for this one on the flickr set ( http://www.flickr.com/photos/[email protected]/sets/72157626476156514/with/5614051491/ ), so I thought I'd post my progress. There's a lot left to be done, but the white shell parts are pretty much finalized. It's a complex model, and rendering will take a while, this is normal. You can change the $fn variable at the beginning to make smoother curves with smaller facets, but the larger the variable, the longer it will take to render. I've been working on other projects, but if/when I finish this, I'll update this space. This model is based on careful measurement of images from screenshots from Portal, Portal 2, and Portal 2 promotional materials. It is actual size, as measured by taking screenshots in which Chell can be seen standing next to the turret, and assuming her to be average height for an adult female. This resulted in an estimate that the standing turret is 1.5m tall including the antenna, and the spheroid portion is 1m tall when folded. Update: thanks to eric1000 for the pics of a 1/10 scale shapeways print! Update 2: The design now has parameters for size (height of the complete spheroid, "full size" is 1000mm) and thickness of the shell in mm. This should make it easier to produce printable STL files. Also, the different parts are now modules that can be easily disabled at the beginning of the file. Update 3: I've successfully printed all of the shell parts on my Makerbot with supports at 1/5 scale. Pictures have been added, and I've posted the STLs I used. Update 4: I've added the black feet and updated the legs with small recesses to insert them into. The scad file is also updated, and includes the code for generating the printable plates.

Print one of each STL raftless with supports. If your supports wont stick, increase their flow rate. The body and arms are split into upper and lower halves, and you can use acetone to solvent weld them together.

comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: All of the files I have are here. The OpenSCAD is the original design, and OpenSCAD only exports meshes, so it's not very interoperable with solidworks. If you really want to try, FreeCAD has a limited ability to read OpenSCAD files, and can also export files that soldworks can read, but I don't know if it's able to translate between the two types of data at all. The constructive solid geometry model of OpenSCAD is really an entirely different paradigm from what solidworks does.

comments.text: Also, if I may, as a low priority, I'd like to suggest that you add some sort of interlock or locating feature between the sections of the body and arm pieces. I had a difficult time getting them to line up and stay lined up while I waited for the epoxy to set.
comments.author: Shamlian

comments.text: I thought about that, but they are designed to be printed raftless with supports on a makerbot or similar printer, and I couldn't think of a good way to do that without interfering with platform adhesion.
comments.author: Shamlian

comments.text: Fair enough. With the machine I have at my disposal, I had some trouble getting the edges to line up, because there was some uneven shrink or deformation of some sort between the halves.  As far as gluing, thanks for the tip. I'm new at this sort of thing. Will acetone bond the ABS halves, even if there is some "daylight?"
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: It's a solvent, so it will melt the plastic that it comes in contact with. Melt the plastic on the edge and press the pieces together, and a little plastic should deform to fill the gaps. You can further seal it by brushing more acetone onto the seam after it sets.

author: wpns

title: "Trick Stick" 3D Printed Xbox One thumb stick replacement

description.text:
Redesigned features for pro gamers in mind. Has a slightly longer thinner shaft for improved accuracy and a domed cap for comfort.
I encourage feedback for additional improvements. Printed using the Robo 3D R1 See instructions.. If you print one, please let us see the results, color choice, material, modifications ect... I am super interested in seeing what you do with this.
Thanks everyone! P.S. My Xbox Live name is DeathAdvice if you want to demonstrate your in game improvements lol.

Print this with the round end facing down!  
Printed in PLA, 100% infill with support  @ .1mm layer height   
-Lightly sand the outside of the lower open round portion with 800 then 1000 grit sandpaper.   
-If you want the top smooth, sand it as well.   
-If you want a rough texture you can hold a metal screen against  the top and point a butane torch or lighter at it for a few seconds. This should give you a knurled effect.(Do this at your own risk!)  
-For a softer grip, consider using a little Plastidip just on the thumb portion. (Pastidip comes in spray or liquid look it up.)  
Post in comments suggested changes or any issues you have with the print.  
Have a great day!!

comments.text: By decreasing the shaft diameter. You over extend the movement of the stick. It will disable your controller. The outer case is the stop for this with the original diameter of the shaft. You can go longer, but thinner is going to destroy the controller.

author: RCMAYHEMGARAGE

title: Quick Change HIC Prusa i3 X-carriage Base Plate

description.text:
I Bought an off the shelf 3D printer and then realised it has many more uses if you can change tools.  But that would be time consuming and involved, so I decided to design a quick change Carriage.  
This is a base plate which stays fixed to the slide bearings on the X-axis carriage. It has a connector for quick disconnection of cables., and a bracket which accepts quick release clamp so different tools can be mounted, ie single head or multiple head or a paste extruder, or even dremel.  
I had a blocked nozzle the quick removal of the entire tool made changing the part so much quicker

you may want to print solid I use a bowden tube system so I have used a 8 pin cable connector to enable quick disconnect and change of tools. If you want a stepper motor on the carriage then you may want a 12 pin connector.
1 Head Heater +ve
2 Head Heater -ve
3 12v +ve
4 12v -ve
5 Fan +ve
6 Fan -ve
7 Head Thermistor
8 Head Thermistor then using a mating female chassis connector for each of the changeable heads. If the chassis mount is connecter to the this carriage it would get in the way. The base has 8 holes to bolt it to the slide bearings, 2 holes for 2 belt connectors (I pushed these into place and glued them using acetone) and further large holes to reduce material. I remixed the extruder and made a bracket for a 4 pin Din connector, just in case see my thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:832550. my stepper motors are colour coded
extruder0 green
x axis red
y axis yellow
z axis blue when printing The slider (I use ABS) i would recommend support. After I printed these parts I found it was too tight a fit, and found that scrapping some material off some edges helped, it needs to be a tight fit though.

Doesn't Matter

Yes

Any

description.text:
Loosely based on Christina Chun's model, but modified so that there is enough clearance for it to fit on an Up! mini.  
Switch screws onto cover and then snaps onto stock extruder body.
New x5 version lowers the switch to eliminate any potential interference with the printer housing (x4 worked fine for me).

author: gapjerjer

title: Simple Bowden E3DV6 hot end carriage

description.text:
A simple Bowden style extruder X carriage mount for a E3DV6   
NOTE:   
On this design the baring shafts (8mm with LM8UU bearings) are in line (vertical) with the drive belt.  
To affix the belt to the unit use a spare strip of drive belt of about 40mm glued into the slot provided on the back then press the drive belt lining up the teeth.
Designed in sketch-up as an upgreade for my own custon built printer to allow me to use a E3DV6

title: OpenSCAD functions for generating PCB mounts

description.text:
Two functions for use in designing cases for PCBs. Define the board size and drill hole positions with an array, then use one function to generate the board mounts and another function to add a dummy board so that the placement can be tested. e.g. myboard = [ 50, 105, //Board size - x,y
10, 10, //Now list x,y positions of board drill holes
40, 15,
15, 80,
35, 90]; board_standoffs(myboard);
dummy_board(myboard);

This thing is to link two chassis to make a 4WD vehicle, still need a bit of work because they tend to touch the ground so I needs some kind of lock to prevent this.

comments.text: I forgot to include the Scad files, here they are in case you want to play with them
comments.author: guibot

comments.text: Also, based off newer trains that use the same method: Add two more wheels to either end, and then add more cars!
comments.author: Austin

comments.text: Err, and maybe a hinge so the thing can corner more easily.
comments.author: Austin

comments.text: Indeed, it seems feasible to make one that'd /snap/ into place, just make it with a spherical cut out of a cylinder, narrow enough so that it only gets slightly smaller than the largest point on the ball...
comments.author: Austin

comments.text: Zero z-freedom answer: Change the geometry from sphere to cylinder.  That eliminates the ability to rotate entirely.
comments.author: MaskedRetriever

comments.text: Oh wait, even more elegant answer: just have the sphere wrap around more of the ball joint.  The closer it goes to fully locking, the less rotation you get.  To have more rotation in one dimension than the other, just make the hole elliptical.

comments.text: Very clever ideas!!!  Thanks!

title: Bongo Tie Rubber Band Cable Fastener

description.text:
This is a replica of the popular Bongo Tie rubber band fastener for holding things together, just add a rubber band!  These are also great for attaching a cable to a pole or two long or bulky objects together.  
It's a few millimeters shorter than the original but this makes it more stable to print and fits better with normal sized rubber bands.  I may add a different sizes in the future.

I printed these in ABS at .2 layer height with 2 shells and 50% hex fill.  
I got it to print with no raft on my heated bed with Kapton but it seems to be easier to use a raft so they don't fall over.

description.text: Do you have a spool that you want to mount on an axel that is too small for it?  This .scad file lets you quickly make a set of two printable "bearings" that will center your spool on your skinny axel.

Measure your axel diameter, and the diameter of the center hole of your spool. The spacer acts as an end cap, to keep the adapters from sliding past the outer edge of the spool, but are also handy for centering spools. This was originally designed for adapting spools to (and centering them on) a tinkertoy spool holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:66975

title: Gimbal Mount For My Rail System

description.text: This is a gimbal mount for my rail system for the DJI Phantom.  Mine fits the rails firmly and slips on smoothly with no vibration what so ever but your mileage may vary.

comments.text:
Thanks for sharing this, was searching for a mount like this.
What are the holes for on the side. Imagine its to hold it in place as the screws, screw on the other part. Is that it?
comments.author: Downloladers

comments.text: The screw holes on the top through the bottom of the mount are for attaching to the gimbal (the top plate is turned 90 degrees).  I threaded M3 screws in the side holes that serve as a clamp against the rail sides to make sure it doesn't slide off in the event of a crash.  They really don't stand out but you can kind of see them in the second photo.  Hope you find it useful.  Good luck and happy flying.
comments.author: Downloladers

author: connor_mark1

title: Da Vinci 3D printer camera mount for GoPro/SJCAM

description.text: I recently bought myself an SJ4000 camera to use it (among other things) as a webcam to monitor long print jobs. Mounting it on the bed platform seemed like the best option for several reasons, but there was nothing like that for the Da Vinci printer, so I set out to model a simple mount that does just that and can then be extended using 'standard' (GoPro compatible) mounts and thumbscrews. This mount just slides in easily but securely into the gaps that exist on both front corners of the bed platform, so the camera can be installed on either side of the bed and then oriented in a wide variety of angles and positions. With the set of two extension arms included you can move the camera both horizontally and vertically with a 60mm radius. These have been created with this fantastic customizer tool, so you may as well easily create your own custom ones.

I printed my set in ABS, at 0.2mm layer height, 50% infill (you want it to be sturdy). The piece that hooks to the bed comes with the required support structures already built in.  
If you choose to print the horizontal extension arm then you'll need to enable support for it on your slicer program.  
Finally, it's likely that you'll need to do some light filing or sanding in the joints for them to fit properly, and also in the holes where the M5 nuts are installed.

comments.text: Pieces don't fit well together for me. I'll try to edit the skp files myself though.
comments.author: j0ckinjz

comments.text: I had to file a bit the gopro connectors for them to fit nicely with each other, but my printer has never been too good with tolerances... anyway, if you do add more tolerance the files and would like me to upload them here I could do that.
comments.author: j0ckinjz

comments.text: doesent work stupid
comments.author: RyleeZimmer

comments.text: Do you find your camera get screaming hot? Mine has been going into thermal shutdown after only 1:30 in the enclosure.. Im trying to figure out a way to fix this but stil get a good video without having to go from outside the enclosure.  Thanks!.

Next week I'll be diving with it in Egypt so that'll be a very good field testing and in a hot environment. Could it be that you got one of those chinese copies that also have troubles with the firmware updates?

Horizontal spool mount for Sunhokey prusa i3 (2015 version)  
Had extra m3 nuts/bolts from the sunhokey kit so I made a spool holder with some 623zz bearings and 3mm rod I had.

Materials:
1 - 20 cm m3 threaded rod or 4-40 threaded rod
4 - 623ZZ bearings
3 - m3 30mm screws
4 - m3 nuts Take out 1 m3 bolt holding the acrylic top piece and thread rod into bottom disc then the nut in the acrylic frame. Careful when tightening the disc onto the frame it's easy to break the acrylic when the disc is turned too tight. Option 1: Use bearing disc and 1 spool cone.
Like this (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:31678)
1 nut for the bottom disc. 3 nuts to hold bearings on the m3 bolts. screw 3 bolts on the bearing disc. 1 bearing in bearing disc. My bearing was loose in the hole so i tightened the m3 screws enough to hold the bearing in place Option 2: Use 2 spool cones no bearings needed.
Like this (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:569454)
I found the bearings are optional for the spool cones. It spins OK without them.

Scanned with ReconstructMe in the Great Fredini's Coney Island Scan-A Rama Booth at Westport CT Makerfaire 4/27/2013. Coney Island Scan-A-Rama is a next generation portrait studio for the 21st century! In the grand tradition of amusement part portraiture, but updated for the era of 3D printing, this popup 3D portrait studio will be appearing at Maker Faires and in Coney Island throughout 2013. For more information or to order prints, please visit http://www.thegreatfredini.com/scan-a-rama
Yes, it's generic and sappy, but it's a great easy way to show them how 3D Printing works.

I printed mine with Glow in Dark to get best effects but forgot to take a photo.
It's not a difficult print once you have print bed level and good adhesion
